   Assessment and Plan
   Mr. [**Known lastname **] is a 64 yo man with dilated cardiomyopathy and severe aortic
   stenosis, OSA & pulmonary hypertension who was admitted to the hospital
   for worsening dyspnea and is transferred to [**Hospital1 1**] for further care.
   .
   # Fever/hyperthermia: differential dx is broad and includes infection,
   drug reaction, or malignant hyperthermia.  His fever predates receipt
   of neuroleptics and he is not rigid to suggest NMS.  He did not receive
   atropine in the cath lab and does not have dilated pupils, making
   anticholinergic syndrome unlikely.  octreotide causes fever in 16-20%
   of patients, which is possible.  Hyperthyroidism could also be
   possible.  Infectious causes are possible, but less commonly cause such
   high fever.  C diff can cause very high fever, toxin-mediate disease
   (like TSS) could also cause such fever (although no skin flushing,
   etc), viral infection (given lymphopenia), etc.  No rash or
   eosinophilia to suggest allergic reaction
   - hold octreotide
   - f/u culture data
   - check TSH
   - consider viral serologies & ID consult in AM.
   - send hemolysis labs
   - consider TTE/TEE to r/o endocarditis
   - treat with vancomycin, cipro, flagyl
   - standing tylenol & cooling blanket
   - hydrate cautiously to replace insensible losses
   .
   # Hypotension: Patient became hypotensive overnight with MAP
s in 40
   Minimally responsive to small IVF boluses therefore was started on
   dopamine however did not tolerate [**1-22**] tachycardia. Changed to levophed
   and tolerating well
   - continue levophed to maintain MAP>55-60
   .
   # Dyspnea: acute on chronic dyspnea is likely multifactorial.  He has
   COPD, severe pulmonary hypertension possibly [**1-22**] COPD, OSA, or other
   causes.  Known chronic systolic heart failure .  His cath lab numbers
   show that he is not in significant pulmonary edema.  Respiratory status
   improved with decreased work of breathing and stable oxygenation
   - continue supplumental oxygen
   - place swan tomorrow and diurese as needed
   - repeat CXR today
   - wean oxygen as tolerated
   .
   # Transaminitis: unclear etiology.  Could represent viral infection,
   versus congestive hepatopathy. US negative for cholangitis or
   cholecystitis.
   - f/u hepatitis B panel, CMV, EBV
   - trend LFT
   .
   # Abdominal pain: Improved both symptomatically and by exam.  KUB
   without evidence of perforation
   - check C diff when able
   - consider CT abdomen today
   - trend LFT
   -f/u final read abdominal U/S
   .
   # UTI: unlikely to be source of such a high fever
   - cont ciprofloxacin
   - f/u urine cx
   .
   # Aortic Stenosis: severe based on gradient and valve area.  Patient
   has had symptoms of refractory heart failure, but no angina or
   syncope.  Depressed EF alone is indication for valve repair.
   - consider referral for valve repair/replacement when stabilizes
   - resume BB when BP's stable
   - consider dobutamine echo to r/o pseudo aortic stenosis
   .
   # Atrial fibrillation: atrial fibrillation with wide complex QRS
   - restart BB when able
   - show EKGs to Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] in AM
   .
   # Diabetes: blood sugars well controlled
   - continue lantus 30U
   - HISS
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia: continue statin
   .
   # Access: placed cordis with RIJ CVC [**2114-4-23**].  Will place swan today for
   better assessment of volume status
   .
   # FEN/GI: restart diet today
   .
   # Code: full

Summary:
The patient is a 64-year-old man with a history of dilated cardiomyopathy, severe aortic stenosis, obstructive sleep apnea, and pulmonary hypertension. He was admitted for worsening dyspnea and is currently in the ICU. The patient has experienced several medical complications, including fever, hypotension, dyspnea, transaminitis, abdominal pain, urinary tract infection (UTI), and atrial fibrillation.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Fever: The patient has a high fever of 105°F, which could be due to various causes such as infection, drug reaction, or malignant hyperthermia. Differential diagnoses include infectious causes, drug-induced fever, hyperthyroidism, or allergic reaction. Further evaluation is needed to determine the underlying cause.

2. Hypotension: The patient became hypotensive overnight with a mean arterial pressure (MAP) in the 40s. Despite receiving intravenous fluids, the patient's blood pressure remains low. The patient was started on dopamine but did not tolerate it due to tachycardia. Levophed was then initiated and the patient is tolerating it well. Continuous monitoring and adjustment of the vasopressor dose will be necessary to maintain a MAP above 55-60 mmHg.

3. Dyspnea: The patient's acute-on-chronic dyspnea is likely multifactorial. Factors contributing to the dyspnea include chronic systolic heart failure

   Mono:2.6 %, Eos:0.1 %, Lactic Acid:3.3 mmol/L, Albumin:3.7 g/dL,
   Ca++:8.8 mg/dL, Mg++:1.8 mg/dL, PO4:5.5 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   Mr. [**Known lastname **] is a 64 yo man with dilated cardiomyopathy and severe aortic
   stenosis, OSA & pulmonary hypertension who was admitted to the hospital
   for worsening dyspnea and is transferred to [**Hospital1 1**] for further care.
   .
   # Fever/hyperthermia: differential dx is broad and includes infection,
   drug reaction, or malignant hyperthermia.  His fever predates receipt
   of neuroleptics and he is not rigid to suggest NMS.  He did not receive
   atropine in the cath lab and does not have dilated pupils, making
   anticholinergic syndrome unlikely.  octreotide causes fever in 16-20%
   of patients, which is possible.  Hyperthyroidism could also be
   possible.  Infectious causes are possible, but less commonly cause such
   high fever.  C diff can cause very high fever, toxin-mediate disease
   (like TSS) could also cause such fever (although no skin flushing,
   etc), viral infection (given lymphopenia), etc.  No rash or
   eosinophilia to suggest allergic reaction
   - hold octreotide
   - f/u culture data
   - check TSH
   - consider viral serologies & ID consult in AM.
   - send hemolysis labs
   - consider TTE/TEE to r/o endocarditis
   - treat with vancomycin, cipro, flagyl
   - standing tylenol & cooling blanket
   - hydrate cautiously to replace insensible losses
   .
   # Dyspnea: likely multifactorial.  He likely became tachypneic from
   fever.  He also has severe pulmonary hypertension, partly from COPD,
   OSA, or other causes.  PE unlikely as patient was anticoagulated for
   most of his hospital stay.  His cath lab numbers show that he is not in
   significant pulmonary edema.
   - continue supplumental oxygen
   - place swan tomorrow and diurese as needed
   .
   # Transaminitis: unclear etiology.  Could represent viral infection,
   versus congestive hepatopathy
   - send hepatitis B panel, CMV, EBV
   - US negative for cholangitis or cholecystitis.
   - monitor
   .
   # Abdominal pain: likely due to hepatitis.  Other possibilities include
   abdominal abscess, C diff colitis (no diarrhea), colonic perforation
   - check C diff
   - would like CT abdomen tomorrow when safe to give 2nd contrast load
   - KUB to r/o perf
   .
   # UTI: unlikely to be source of such a high fever
   - ciprofloxacin
   .
   # Aortic Stenosis: severe based on gradient and valve area.  Patient
   has had symptoms of refractory heart failure, but no angina or
   syncope.  Depressed EF alone is indication for valve repair.
   - consider balloon angioplasty when stabilizes
   - resume BB when BP's stable
   - swan in AM
   - consider dobutamine echo to r/o pseudo aortic stenosis
   .
   # Arryhthmia: EKG's have had very unsual evolution: with completely
   different axis.  Rate irregular, which makes VT seem unlikely (but not
   completely impossible).  No evidence for bypass tract on prior EKg to
   suggest A fib with abberant conduction.
   - restart BB when able
   - show EKGs to Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] in AM
   .
   # Diabetes: decrease lantus to 26 while not eating much
   .
   # hyperlipidemia: continue statin
   .
   # Access: placed chordus with RIJ CVC [**2114-4-23**].  Will place swan in AM
   .
   # FEN/GI: clears while unstable/poor mental status.
   .
   # Code: full

Summary:
The patient is a 64-year-old man with a history of dilated cardiomyopathy, severe aortic stenosis, OSA, and pulmonary hypertension. He was admitted to the hospital for worsening dyspnea and is now in the ICU. He has had a fever of 105°F, which was treated with Tylenol and cooling blankets. The patient's blood pressure has been unstable, requiring IV fluids and the use of dopamine and norepinephrine. He has also received midazolam and haloperidol for sedation.

Potential medical complications that can arise:
1. Infection: The patient's high fever could be due to an infection, and further investigation is needed to determine the cause.
2. Drug reaction: The fever may also be a reaction to one of the medications the patient is receiving.
3. Malignant hyperthermia: This is a rare reaction to certain anesthetic drugs, which can cause a rapid increase in body temperature.
4. Anticholinergic syndrome: The patient did not receive atropine in the cath lab, making this less likely.
5. Hyperthyroidism: This could be a possible cause of the fever, especially considering the patient's lymphopenia.
6. Septic shock: The patient's unstable blood pressure and the need for aggressive resuscitation suggest the possibility of septic shock.
7. Endocarditis: A transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE)

Summary:
The patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of dilated cardiomyopathy, severe aortic stenosis, obstructive sleep apnea, and pulmonary hypertension. He was admitted for worsening dyspnea and transferred to the ICU for further care. The patient experienced a fever overnight, which has since defervesced. He also presented with hypotension that was initially unresponsive to IV fluids but responded to dopamine and then levophed. The patient's leukocyte count is elevated, and he has acute on chronic dyspnea with multiple potential contributing factors including COPD, severe pulmonary hypertension, and chronic systolic heart failure. The patient's transaminase levels are elevated, but the etiology is unclear. He also has abdominal pain, but an abdominal ultrasound did not reveal any evidence of perforation. Additionally, the patient has a urinary tract infection, severe aortic stenosis, atrial fibrillation with wide complex QRS, well-controlled diabetes, hyperlipidemia, and a new central venous catheter placement. The patient's condition requires close monitoring and management of various medical complications.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:
1. Infection: The patient has a fever and elevated white blood cell count, suggesting a possible infection. Close monitoring for signs of infection and appropriate antibiotic therapy should be continued.
2. Septic shock: The patient's hypotension and requirement for vasopressors (dopamine and levophed)

Summary:
The patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of nonischemic dilated cardiomyopathy, severe aortic stenosis, rheumatic mitral stenosis, diabetes mellitus, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), obstructive sleep apnea, and pulmonary hypertension. He was admitted to the hospital due to dyspnea on exertion and was transferred for further evaluation of his severe aortic stenosis. The patient is currently in the ICU and is being treated for septic shock caused by bacteremia with coagulase-positive Staphylococcus. He has multiple comorbidities including dilated cardiomyopathy with an ejection fraction of 25%, severe aortic stenosis, and rheumatic mitral stenosis.

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 102.0°F, heart rate of 93 beats per minute, blood pressure of 107/65 mmHg, respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute, oxygen saturation of 94%, and atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response. His physical examination reveals crackles at the bases of the lungs, a harsh systolic murmur at the base, and trace edema in the lower extremities.

The patient's laboratory results show leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 17.6 thousand/mm3, elevated creatinine levels, elevated liver enzymes (ALT and AST), low albumin level, elevated lactate level, and elevated troponin-T level. Blood cultures are positive for coagulase-positive Staphylococcus.

The patient's imaging studies reveal severe global left ventricular hypokinesis with an ejection fraction of 20-30%, severe aortic stenosis, mild mitral stenosis, moderate mitral regurgitation, and severe pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. The transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) does not show any valvular vegetations, but imaging of the aortic valve is limited by severe valvular sclerosis.

The patient has several medical complications, including septic shock, acute kidney injury (likely due to contrast nephropathy from a recent cardiac catheterization), acute respiratory failure, liver failure (with unclear etiology), anemia (possibly due to gastrointestinal bleeding from a colonic arteriovenous malformation), and atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response.

The patient's current plan includes titrating levophed to maintain ScvO2>70%, placing a Swan-Ganz catheter for better hemodynamic monitoring, maintaining CVP>7-10 mmHg, maintaining hematocrit >30%, trending lactate levels, continuing vancomycin, discontinuing ciprofloxacin and flagyl, obtaining additional information regarding prior history, and consulting with a cardiothoracic surgeon for possible aortic valve repair.

Summary:
The patient is a 64-year-old male with nonischemic dilated cardiomyopathy, severe aortic stenosis, rheumatic mitral stenosis, diabetes mellitus, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, obstructive sleep apnea, and pulmonary hypertension. He was admitted to the hospital for dyspnea on exertion and transferred for further evaluation of aortic stenosis. He now presents with gram-positive cocci bacteremia, septic shock, and possible enterococcal translocation.

The patient's condition is unstable with high fever that has defervesced, increasing white blood cell count, improving perfusion but still requiring substantial vasopressor support, and a hematocrit level at goal. He has severe aortic stenosis with reduced left ventricular ejection fraction and minimal mitral stenosis. There is also evidence of global left ventricular hypokinesis, right ventricular hypertrophy and dysfunction, and severe pulmonary artery systolic hypertension.

The patient's recent medical history includes a colonoscopy with cauterization of colonic arteriovenous malformation, which could potentially be related to anemia of unclear etiology. There is also evidence of transaminitis, possibly due to congestive hepatopathy or viral hepatitis. The patient has been diagnosed with atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response.

The patient's current medications include vancomycin, ciprofloxacin, metronidazole, norepinephrine,

He was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) due to difficulty breathing on exertion (DOE) and is currently being evaluated for severe AS. The patient has also been diagnosed with bacteremia caused by coag-positive staphylococci and is suspected to have sepsis.

The patient's medical complications include:

1. Septic condition: The patient is experiencing sepsis likely caused by coag-positive staphylococci bacteremia. He is on appropriate antibiotic therapy, but his condition requires close monitoring. Pressor requirements are still substantial, and a Swan-Ganz catheter has been placed for better hemodynamic monitoring.

2. Acute on chronic systolic heart failure: The patient had an acute episode of dyspnea overnight, which may be related to increased fluids. However, he improved without diuresis. The low suspicion for pulmonary embolism (PE) is due to the absence of hypoxia, and the negative lower extremity Doppler ultrasound (LENI) further reduces the likelihood of PE.

Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 64-year-old woman with a medical history of nonischemic dilated cardiomyopathy, severe aortic stenosis, rheumatic mitral stenosis, diabetes mellitus, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), obstructive sleep apnea, and pulmonary hypertension. She was admitted to the hospital for evaluation of aortic stenosis and is now presenting with gram-positive cocci bacteremia, which may be related to streptococcal or enterococcal translocation. There is a concern for possible endocarditis, especially given her history of rheumatic heart disease.

The patient's current condition includes:
- Fever with a maximum temperature of 102.0°F (38.9°C)
- Tachycardia with a heart rate of 93 beats per minute
- Hypotension with blood pressure ranging from 107/65 mmHg to 71/37 mmHg
- Tachypnea with a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute
- Oxygen saturation of 94% on nasal cannula
- Atrial fibrillation with an irregular heart rhythm
- Limited physical examination due to the patient's condition
- Elevated white blood cell count
- Elevated blood glucose levels
- Abnormal liver function tests
- Abnormal kidney function with acute kidney injury

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of nonischemic dilated cardiomyopathy, severe aortic stenosis, rheumatic mitral stenosis, diabetes mellitus, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, obstructive sleep apnea, and pulmonary hypertension. The patient presented to the emergency department with dyspnea on exertion and was transferred to the ICU for further evaluation of severe aortic stenosis. On admission, the patient had a high fever and was found to have bacteremia caused by Group B Streptococcus (GPC). The patient's condition has been complicated by sepsis, acute kidney injury, acute respiratory distress syndrome, hepatic dysfunction, and anemia.

The patient underwent several diagnostic tests, including a transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE), transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE), and an ultrasound of the legs. The TTE showed severe global left ventricular hypokinesis with an ejection fraction of 20-30%, severe aortic stenosis, mild mitral stenosis, and moderate mitral regurgitation. The TEE did not show any valvular vegetations but was limited by severe valvular sclerosis. A CT scan of the abdomen was also performed, which showed a colonic arteriovenous malformation (AVM) that was cauterized.

The patient's current condition is stable, but he remains at risk

Summary:
The patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of nonischemic dilated cardiomyopathy, severe aortic stenosis, rheumatic mitral stenosis, diabetes mellitus, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), obstructive sleep apnea, and pulmonary hypertension. He presented to the hospital with dyspnea on exertion and was transferred for further evaluation of aortic stenosis. On admission, he was found to have GPC bacteremia and septicemia, possibly related to a recent colonoscopy. He also has an increasing white blood cell count, indicating ongoing infection. The patient's hemodynamics are being supported with norepinephrine and dobutamine infusions. His ejection fraction is severely reduced at 20-30%. 

The patient has undergone a transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) and transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE), which revealed severe aortic stenosis with severely reduced left ventricular ejection fraction. There is also evidence of moderate pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. No vegetations were seen on the TEE, ruling out endocarditis. 

The patient's liver function tests (LFTs) are abnormal, showing a hepatitis pattern of unclear etiology. This could be due to congestive hepatopathy or viral hepatitis. 

He is currently on multiple medications including vancomycin, ciprofloxacin, metronidazole, pantopraz

- The patient has been diagnosed with chronic diastolic heart failure (CHF) and knowledge deficit.
- They are also experiencing acute respiratory failure, not ARDS.
- The patient has atrial fibrillation (AFIB), hypotension that is not in shock, and aortic stenosis.
- The patient has a fever, which is not of unknown origin.

The patient's vital signs show an elevated heart rate (85 bpm), low blood pressure (100/59 mmHg), and a slightly elevated body temperature (37.8 C). The patient is receiving dobutamine, lasix, norepinephrine, heparin sodium, and other medications.

The lab results indicate elevated levels of white blood cells, hemoglobin, and troponin T. There are also elevated levels of liver enzymes (ALT/AST), amylase, lipase, lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), and D-dimer. The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal range.

The potential medical complications that can arise from these conditions include worsening heart failure, exacerbation of respiratory failure, development of deep vein thrombosis (DVT), stress ulcer bleeding, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).

It is crucial to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, administer appropriate medications, and provide adequate supportive care to manage these

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 64-year-old male with a medical history of nonischemic dilated cardiomyopathy (ejection fraction 25%), severe aortic stenosis (AS), rheumatic mitral stenosis (MS), diabetes mellitus (DM), chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), and pulmonary hypertension. The patient was admitted with dyspnea on exertion (DOE) and transferred for further evaluation of AS. Currently, the patient is being treated for septic shock caused by methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) bacteremia.

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 37.8°C (100.7°F), heart rate of 85 beats per minute, blood pressure ranging from 100/59 mmHg to 81/51 mmHg, respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, oxygen saturation of 99%, and atrial fibrillation with a regularized rhythm.

The patient's physical examination reveals findings consistent with severe AS and MS, including a harsh systolic murmur at the base, fine crackles at the bases, and no wheezes or rhonchi. Neurological examination is normal, and the patient is awake, alert, and oriented to time, place, and person.

Laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, increased lactate levels, elevated liver enzymes

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 64-year-old male with nonischemic dilated cardiomyopathy, severe aortic stenosis, rheumatic mitral stenosis, diabetes mellitus, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, obstructive sleep apnea, and pulmonary hypertension. He was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) with dyspnea on exertion, transferred for further evaluation of aortic stenosis, and now presents with gram-positive cocci bacteremia and septic shock.

The patient remains afebrile with decreasing white blood cell count. His perfusion is improving, but he still requires substantial pressor support. A Swan-Ganz catheter was placed to monitor his hemodynamics, revealing volume overload based on the pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP) of 36 mmHg. The central venous pressure (CVP) improved with diuresis overnight. The plan includes weaning levophed as able to maintain mean arterial pressure (MAP) >65 mmHg, uptitration of dobutamine as tolerated by heart rate to maintain superior vena oxygen saturation (ScvO2) >70%, maintaining CVP between 7-30 mmHg, maintaining hematocrit (Hct) >30%, rewedge today, and continue vancomycin.

Additional medical complications include liver failure with elevated liver enzymes, acute on chronic systolic heart failure with ongoing volume overload, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease,

Summary:
The patient is a 64-year-old male with a medical history of nonischemic dilated cardiomyopathy, severe aortic stenosis, rheumatic mitral stenosis, diabetes mellitus, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, obstructive sleep apnea, and pulmonary hypertension. He was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for further evaluation of aortic stenosis and is now presenting with infective endocarditis caused by methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) bacteremia.

The patient's current condition includes:

1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient has a low blood pressure, low cardiac output, and is dependent on vasopressors and inotropic support.
2. Atrial fibrillation: The patient has an irregularly irregular rhythm with a rapid ventricular response.
3. Severe aortic stenosis: The patient has a significant narrowing of the aortic valve, which is causing symptoms of heart failure.
4. Rheumatic mitral stenosis: The patient has a narrowing of the mitral valve due to previous rheumatic fever.
5. Diabetes mellitus: The patient has well-controlled diabetes and is on basal and short-acting insulin.
6. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD): The patient has chronic airflow limitation and is on albuterol nebs.
7. Obstructive sleep apnea: The patient has sleep-disordered breathing.

Summary:
The patient is a 64-year-old male with nonischemic dilated cardiomyopathy, severe aortic stenosis, rheumatic mitral stenosis, diabetes mellitus, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, obstructive sleep apnea, and pulmonary hypertension. He was admitted for further evaluation of aortic stenosis but developed septic shock due to MSSA bacteremia. The patient remains afebrile with decreasing white count and improving perfusion. He is volume overloaded based on his PCWP of 36 and CVP improved with diuresis overnight. The patient is currently on dobutamine and lasix infusions and is being weaned off levophed. Swan-Ganz catheter was placed yesterday to better monitor hemodynamics. The patient's liver function tests are still trending up with a pattern suggestive of hepatitis, possibly related to congestive hepatopathy. Surgical repair of aortic stenosis may be considered after clearing the infection. The patient also has acute on chronic systolic heart failure with symptoms of dyspnea overnight that improved without diuresis. He has acute episodes of COPD, pulmonary hypertension, and anxiety, as well as anxiety-related dyspnea. The patient's abdominal pain has improved, and there is no evidence of perforation or source of pain on RUQ ultrasound. He has acute renal failure possibly due to ATN or contrast nephropathy. The patient's hemoglobin levels are stable, and there is no evidence

He was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for further evaluation of AS and is now presenting with gram-positive cocci bacteremia, likely caused by methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA). The patient has septic shock and is requiring vasopressors for hemodynamic support.

The patient has multiple medical complications, including acute kidney injury (AKI) with an elevated creatinine level, liver dysfunction with elevated liver enzymes, anemia, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, and hyperlipidemia. He also has back pain, which is suspicious for possible infection given his bacteremia and fever.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of nonischemic dilated cardiomyopathy, severe aortic stenosis, rheumatic mitral stenosis, diabetes mellitus, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), obstructive sleep apnea, and pulmonary hypertension. He was admitted to the hospital with dyspnea on exertion and transferred for further evaluation of aortic stenosis. He now presents with MSSA bacteremia, septicemia, and liver failure. He has a history of gastrointestinal bleeding with colonic arteriovenous malformation that was cauterized. He also has acute kidney injury, anemia, thrombocytopenia, atrial fibrillation, back pain, diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and a central line. His current condition includes volume overload, hypotension, tachycardia, hypoxemia, and oliguria.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Cardiac Complications:
   - Cardiogenic shock due to severe aortic stenosis and septicemia.
   - Arrhythmias such as ventricular tachycardia or ventricular fibrillation due to atrial fibrillation and electrolyte imbalances.
   - Acute heart failure exacerbation due to fluid overload and reduced cardiac output.

2. Infection-related Complications:
   - Sepsis and septic shock due to MSSA bacteremia.
   - Pneumonia

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of nonischemic dilated cardiomyopathy, severe aortic stenosis (AS), rheumatic mitral stenosis (MS), diabetes mellitus (DM), chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), and pulmonary hypertension. He was admitted to the hospital with dyspnea on exertion and was transferred for further evaluation of AS. The patient is now presenting with MSSA bacteremia and septicemia. 

Assessment and Plan:

1. Septicemia caused by MSSA bacteremia: The patient remains afebrile with decreasing white count. His perfusion is improving as indicated by ScvO2. However, he still requires substantial pressor support. A Swan-Ganz catheter was placed yesterday, revealing volume overload based on the pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP) of 36. The central venous pressure (CVP) has improved with diuresis overnight. The plan includes weaning off levophed as able to maintain mean arterial pressure (MAP) >65, uptitrating dobutamine as tolerated to maintain ScvO2 >70%, maintaining CVP >7-30 mmHg, maintaining hematocrit (Hct) >30%, rewedge today, continuing vancomycin, obtaining additional information regarding prior history of MRSA infection, and serial blood cultures.

2.

Summary:
The patient is a 69-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of sepsis without organ dysfunction. The patient's blood cultures have identified MSSA, and he has been started on vancomycin and nafcillin. The patient has diuresed over 3.5L at 1500 with MAP's in the high 50-60's and was unable to wean off levophed. Lasix was held, and the patient received 250cc IVF at 2104, with another 250cc IVF at 2300. The patient's liver enzyme levels are likely indicative of shock liver, and an abdominal ultrasound with doppler is recommended along with supportive care. The patient also has trouble weaning levophed, likely due to intravascular volume depletion from overdiuresis.

The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation, chronic diastolic heart failure, knowledge deficit, acute respiratory failure (not ARDS), aortic stenosis, hypotension (not in shock), fever (hypothermia, pyrexia, not fever of unknown origin), and sepsis without organ dysfunction.

He was admitted for evaluation of aortic stenosis and now presents with gram-positive cocci bacteremia and septic shock. The patient has been on multiple medications, including nafcillin, dobutamine, levophed, lasix, and heparin. He is currently in cardiogenic shock and appears to be volume overloaded based on clinical examination and rising pulmonary pressures. 1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient is still requiring significant pressor support, indicating ongoing cardiogenic shock. Weaning off levophed may be challenging due to the patient's volume overload and high pulmonary artery pressures.

The patient has a history of acute kidney injury (AKI) due to atrial fibrillation (AF), liver failure, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), and anemia. He is currently receiving dobutamine and lasix for cardiogenic shock, nafcillin for MSSA bacteremia, and other medications for his various conditions.

1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient is experiencing cardiogenic shock, which is a life-threatening condition where the heart cannot pump enough blood to meet the body's needs. The use of dobutamine and lasix may help support cardiac output, but careful monitoring of blood pressure and heart rate is essential to prevent further complications.

2. MSSA bacteremia: The patient has MSSA bacteremia, which is a serious infection caused by methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus. Continuing nafcillin therapy and monitoring blood cultures are important to prevent the spread of infection and identify any antibiotic resistance.

Summary:
The patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of nonischemic dilated cardiomyopathy, severe aortic stenosis, rheumatic mitral stenosis, diabetes mellitus, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, obstructive sleep apnea, and pulmonary hypertension. He was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) due to dyspnea on exertion, transferred for further evaluation of aortic stenosis, and now presents with gram-positive cocci bacteremia and septic shock.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient appears to be volume overloaded based on the clinical exam and rising pulmonary pressures with a pulmonary artery diastolic pressure (PAD) of 34 this morning. Levophed was discontinued this AM, and it will be monitored whether the patient still requires significant pressure support. The plan is to wean levophed as tolerated to maintain mean arterial pressure (MAP) >60 after diuresis.
2. MSSA bacteremia: The patient remains afebrile with a stable white blood cell count. It is important to maintain hematocrit (Hct) >30%, continue nafcillin to complete a 2-week course, and follow up with serial blood cultures (pending).
3. Liver failure: Liver function tests (LFTs) are trending down, and the patient has been diagnosed with shock liver by the liver team. An ultrasound was negative for cholangitis or cholec

The patient was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) with dyspnea on exertion and was transferred for further evaluation of aortic stenosis. Currently, the patient is experiencing cardiogenic shock and septic shock due to MSSA bacteremia.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is in the ICU with a chief complaint of septic/cardiogenic shock. The patient has been diagnosed with several conditions, including sepsis without organ dysfunction, heart failure (diastolic), chronic, respiratory failure, acute (not ARDS), atrial fibrillation, hypotension (not shock), aortic stenosis, fever (hypothermia, pyrexia, not fever of unknown origin), and knowledge deficit.

The patient's vital signs show a blood pressure of 89/68 mmHg, heart rate of 91 bpm, respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%. The patient's weight is 121.1 kg, and height is 69 inches.

The patient has been receiving various medications and infusions, including furosemide (Lasix), heparin sodium, and dobutamine. The patient also has multiple lines, including a PA catheter inserted on 04/25/2114 at 03:00 PM.

Laboratory results show an elevated white blood cell count of 14.4 K/uL, decreased hemoglobin level of 9.9 g/dL, elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 125 mg/dL, increased creatinine level of 2.0, elevated lactate level of 1.4 mmol/L, and elevated D-dimer level of [**Numeric Identifier 5835**] ng/mL.

The patient's blood cultures were positive on 04/26/2114 at 04:30 AM, 04:55 AM, 01:54 PM, and 10:16 PM. The patient's platelet count has been falling over time, and there is a suspicion of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) based on the 4Ts score of [**3-25**].

Potential medical complications that can arise include worsening septic/cardiogenic shock, progression of heart failure, development of organ dysfunction, further decrease in platelet count leading to bleeding complications, and potential adverse effects from medications and interventions.

The patient requires close monitoring and management of their vital signs, fluid balance, electrolyte levels, and ongoing evaluation of their respiratory status. Prompt intervention may be necessary to address any complications that may arise.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of nonischemic dilated cardiomyopathy, severe aortic stenosis, rheumatic mitral stenosis, diabetes mellitus, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, obstructive sleep apnea, and pulmonary hypertension. He was admitted for dyspnea on exertion and transferred for further evaluation of aortic stenosis. The patient is now diagnosed with methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) bacteremia, septic shock, and cardiogenic shock.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient is currently experiencing cardiogenic shock, which is being managed by titrating dobutamine to maintain cardiac index (CI) >2.5, adjusting lasix infusion to achieve urine output (UOP) of 100-150 cc/hr, and monitoring PCWP, ScvO2, CI, and SVR every 8 hours. Levophed should be weaned as tolerated to maintain mean arterial pressure (MAP) >65 after diuresis, and Hct should be maintained >30%.

2. Acute on chronic congestive heart failure (CHF): The patient's acute on chronic CHF is related to fluid resuscitation for sepsis. Management includes lasix infusion with lasix bolus to achieve a negative fluid balance of 1-2 liters within 24 hours and consideration of a wedge pressure if able

   and I agree with the documentation of the events over the past 24

   treatment plan as outlined above accurately reflect our plans for
   therapy over the next 24 hours.   Mr. [**Known lastname **] is symptomatically improved
   over the past 24 hours.  He still complains of back pain but his
   dyspnea is better.  His physical examination shows better rate control
   of his atrial fibrillation on amiodarone and improved lung fields.  His
   pulmonary artery pressures remain elevated and we will continue
   diuresis with dobutamine ionotropic support.  His LFTs are also
   improving.  We have consulted our cardiac surgery colleagues and will
   review the options of balloon valvuloplasty if this is needed to assess
   the response to his pulmonary hypertension to aortic valve dilation
   after completion of his treatment for staph sepsis.  [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 3139**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 5279**], MD

s trending down; U/S neg

   .

   shock, liver failure; low-intermediate prob for HIT; no evidence DIC by

   .

   surgery
   -appreciate CT [**Doctor First Name **] consult
   .

   Non-oliguric with improving renal indices
   -cont trend UOP, Cr
   .

 Hct stable; unclear baseline; recent GIB w/ C-scope showing

   -trend Hct daily
   .

   -restart BB when hemodynamically stable
   -cont heparin gtt
   .

   -low dose narcotics prn
   -limit tylenol
   -consider imaging of back if pain worsens or neuro status changes
   .

 well-controlled

- The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 37.4°C, heart rate of 98 bpm, blood pressure of 94/58 mmHg, respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 95%.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Cardiogenic Shock: The patient's heart function is compromised due to severe aortic stenosis and rheumatic mitral stenosis. There is a risk of further deterioration in cardiac output and hemodynamic instability.
2. Septic Shock: The patient has MSSA bacteremia, which can lead to septic shock.

   64 M w/ nonischemic dilated cardiomyopathy (EF 25%), severe AS,
   rheumatic MS, DM, COPD, OSA & pulm HTN admitted to OSH with DOE,
   transferred for further evaluation of AS, now with MSSA bacteremia,

   # Cardiogenic shock
 stable. Has been off of Levophed for >24 hours
   now.
   -decrease dobutamine today  to maintain CI>2.5; maintain this morning
   to aid in diuresis; decrease to 5mg/hour this afternoon or tomorrow
   morning in attempt to wean
 monitor cardiac output and diuresis
   closely
   -titrate lasix gtt to UOP>100-150cc/hr, goal neg -1L x 24 hrs
   -repeat PCWP/ScvO2/CI/SVR q8h
   -maintain Hct>30%
   -continue to hold levophed at this time
   .
   # Acute on chronic CHF
 Related to fluid resuscitation for sepsis
   -Lasix gtt with Lasix bolus for goal 1L negative
   -wedge if able
   -watch output closely so as not to exacerbate cardiogenic shock
   .
   #  MSSA bacteremia - unclear source; WBC# and fever curve trending
   down, surveillance Cx neg
   -cont nafcillin to complete a 2 week course (day #1=[**2114-4-24**])
   .
   #Liver failure
 [**1-22**] multifactorial shock, LFT
s trending down; U/S neg
   for infectious involvement
   -appreciate liver consult
   -trend LFT's
   -avoid hepatotoxic medications
   -tylenol 2gm max/24 hrs
   .
   #Hyperbilirubinemia
 Direct. Source unclear. Alkaline phosphatase not
   elevated. RUQ ultrasound on admission without evidence of
   cholecystitis. Could this be [**Doctor Last Name **]
   - Monitor daily
   #Nausea
 New since last evening. Differential diagnosis includes SBO
   (no BM since admission), cholecystitis (no evidence on admission RUQ
   ultrasound), cardiac equivalent, pancreatitis, gastropathy given DM,
   medication side effect (?morphine)
   - KUB
   - Aggressive bowel regimen
   - Limit morphine limit to assess for improvement
   #Thrombocytopenia
 Platelets stable. Likely a component of shock,
   liver failure; low-intermediate prob for HIT; no evidence DIC by labs
   -follow HIT antibody
   -trend daily
   -appreciate heme/onc recs
   .
   #AS - [**Location (un) **] 0.8 cm2 in cath lab; surgical repair candidate given symptoms
   of CHF however will need to clear infection prior to consideration for
   surgery
   -appreciate CT [**Doctor First Name **] consult
   .
   #ARF
Slowly increasing. [**1-22**] ATN in the setting of shock +/- contrast
   nephropathy
   -cont trend UOP, Cr
   .
   #Anemia
 Hct stable; unclear baseline; recent GIB w/ C-scope showing
   colonic AVM that was cauterized
   -trend Hct daily
   .
   # Afib - rate-related aberrancy
   - starting digoxin today
   - may d/p EP in coming days re BiV placement
   -restart BB when hemodynamically stable
   -cont heparin gtt
   .
   #Low back pain
 presumed [**1-22**] chronic lumbar back disease, but will
   monitor for evidence of complication of bacteremia (epidural abscess)
   -low dose narcotics prn
   -limit tylenol
   -consider imaging of back if pain worsens or neuro status changes
   .

 well-controlled
   -cont basal, SS insulin
   .

   -cont statin

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is a 64-year-old male with nonischemic dilated cardiomyopathy, severe aortic stenosis (AS), rheumatic mitral stenosis (MS), diabetes mellitus (DM), chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), and pulmonary hypertension (pHTN).
- The patient was admitted for dyspnea on exertion (DOE) and evaluation of AS. He is now being treated for methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) bacteremia, septic shock, and cardiogenic shock.
- The patient's current medical conditions include cardiogenic shock, acute on chronic heart failure (CHF) due to fluid resuscitation for sepsis, MSSA bacteremia, liver failure, hyperbilirubinemia, nausea, thrombocytopenia, aortic stenosis, acute renal failure (ARF), anemia, atrial fibrillation (AFib), low back pain, diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and obesity.
- The patient has had multiple interventions including cardiac catheterization, administration of nafcillin, dobutamine, lasix, and heparin.
- The patient's vital signs are as follows: temperature (T) 36.6°C, heart rate (HR) 103 bpm, blood pressure (BP) 82/51 mmHg, respiratory rate (RR) 14 breaths per minute, oxygen saturation (SpO2) 96%, and atrial fibrillation.
- The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count (WBC), elevated blood glucose levels, elevated liver enzymes, elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), low platelet count, and abnormal kidney function tests.
- The patient has been placed on various medications including nafcillin, dobutamine, lasix, ranitidine, furosemide, and morphine sulfate.
- The patient's current disposition is critical care unit (CCU) with full code status.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient is already experiencing cardiogenic shock, which is a life-threatening condition that requires close monitoring and management.
2. Acute on chronic CHF: The patient has acute on chronic CHF due to fluid resuscitation for sepsis. This condition needs to be closely monitored to prevent further deterioration.
3. MSSA bacteremia: The patient has MSSA bacteremia, which needs to be treated appropriately to prevent complications such as septic shock and endocarditis.
4. Liver failure: The patient is showing signs of liver failure, which may be multifactorial in origin. Close monitoring of liver function tests and appropriate management are necessary.
5. Hyperbilirubinemia: The patient has hyperbilirubinemia with direct bilirubin elevation.

   Assessment and Plan
   64 M w/ nonischemic dilated cardiomyopathy (EF 25%), severe AS,
   rheumatic MS, DM, COPD, OSA & pulm HTN admitted to OSH with DOE,
   transferred for further evaluation of AS, now with MSSA bacteremia,
   septic shock, and cardiogenic shock.
   .
   # Cardiogenic shock
 stable. Has been off of Levophed for >24 hours
   now.
   -cont dobutamine at 7.5mg/hour to maintain CI>2.5; maintain this
   morning to aid in diuresis; decrease to 5mg/hour this afternoon or
   tomorrow morning in attempt to wean
 monitor cardiac output and
   diuresis closely
   -titrate lasix gtt to UOP>100-150cc/hr, goal neg -1L x 24 hrs
   -repeat PCWP/ScvO2/CI/SVR q8h
   -maintain Hct>30%
   -continue to hold levophed at this time
   .
   # Acute on chronic CHF
 Related to fluid resuscitation for sepsis
   -Lasix gtt with Lasix bolus for goal 1L negative
   -wedge if able
   -watch output closely so as not to exacerbate cardiogenic shock
   .
   #  MSSA bacteremia - unclear source; WBC# and fever curve trending
   down, surveillance Cx neg
   -cont nafcillin to complete a 2 week course (day #1=[**2114-4-24**])
   .
   #Liver failure
 [**1-22**] multifactorial shock, LFT
s trending down; U/S neg
   for infectious involvement
   -appreciate liver consult
   -trend LFT's
   -avoid hepatotoxic medications
   -tylenol 2gm max/24 hrs
   .
   #Thrombocytopenia
 platelets cont trend down, multifactorial [**1-22**]
   shock, liver failure; low-intermediate prob for HIT; no evidence DIC by
   labs
   -cont heparin products for now
   -trend daily
   -heme c/s re: HIT Ab assay & initiation of fondaparinux vs argatroban
   (given hepatic and renal dysfunction)
   .
   #AS - [**Location (un) **] 0.8 cm2 in cath lab; surgical repair candidate given symptoms
   of CHF however will need to clear infection prior to consideration for
   surgery
   -appreciate CT [**Doctor First Name **] consult
   .
   #ARF
[**1-22**] ATN in the setting of shock +/- contrast nephropathy.
   Non-oliguric with improving renal indices
   -cont trend UOP, Cr
   .
   #Anemia
 Hct stable; unclear baseline; recent GIB w/ C-scope showing
   colonic AVM that was cauterized
   -trend Hct daily
   .
   # Afib - rate-related aberrancy
   -restart BB when hemodynamically stable
   -cont heparin gtt
   .
   #Low back pain
 presumed [**1-22**] chronic lumbar back disease, but will
   monitor for evidence of complication of bacteremia (epidural abscess)
   -low dose narcotics prn
   -limit tylenol
   -consider imaging of back if pain worsens or neuro status changes
   .
   #DM
 well-controlled
   -cont basal, SS insulin
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia
   -cont statin
   .
   #Access: Cordis/RIJ [**2114-4-23**]
   #Nutrition: low Na/HH/DM diet replete lytes prn
   # Code: FULL
   #Dispo: CCU

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of nonischemic dilated cardiomyopathy, severe aortic stenosis, rheumatic mitral stenosis, diabetes mellitus, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, obstructive sleep apnea, and pulmonary hypertension. He was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for further evaluation of aortic stenosis and is now being treated for methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) bacteremia, septic shock, and cardiogenic shock.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Cardiogenic Shock: The patient's cardiogenic shock is currently stable, but close monitoring of cardiac output and diuresis is necessary. Dobutamine will be continued at 7.5mg/hour to maintain cardiac index (CI) >2.5.
2. Acute on Chronic Congestive Heart Failure (CHF): Due to fluid resuscitation for sepsis, the patient may develop acute on chronic CHF. Lasix will be given through a continuous infusion with a goal of negative 1 liter urine output per hour.
3. MSSA Bacteremia: The source of MSSA bacteremia is unclear, so surveillance cultures will be negative. Nafcillin will be continued for a total of 2 weeks.
4. Liver Failure: The patient's liver function tests (LFTs) are trending down, and a liver consult has been requested

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 69-year-old male with a history of chronic conditions including atrial fibrillation, diastolic heart failure, aortic stenosis, and chronic pain. The patient was admitted to the ICU with acute respiratory failure, sepsis without organ dysfunction, acute thrombocytopenia, and knowledge deficit. The patient's vital signs are stable with a temperature of 36.2°C, heart rate of 103 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 82/51 to 106/79 mmHg, respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation at 96%. The patient is on heparin sodium infusion and receiving various medications including lasix, ranitidine, furosemide, and morphine sulfate. The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, slightly low hemoglobin levels, elevated blood glucose levels, and abnormal liver function tests. The patient's chest X-ray shows no acute infiltrates or effusions. The patient's arterial blood gas analysis reveals mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis. The patient's physical examination is significant for crackles at the bases of the lungs and 1+ lower extremity edema. 

Potential Medical Complications:
Based on the provided information, potential medical complications for this patient may include worsening heart failure, respiratory failure, sepsis progressing to septic shock, thromboembolic events such as deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism

The patient is now presenting with methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus bacteremia, septic shock, and cardiogenic shock.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 36.4°C, heart rate of 88 bpm, blood pressure of 95/51 mmHg, respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98%. The patient is in atrial fibrillation with an irregularly irregular rhythm. Physical examination reveals fine crackles at the lung bases, no wheezes or rhonchi, and warm dry extremities with 1+ lower extremity edema to midcalves bilaterally.

Laboratory findings include a white blood cell count of 13.4 K/uL, hemoglobin of 9.6 g/dL, platelet count of 92 K/uL, creatinine of 1.7 mg/dL, blood glucose of 125 mg/dL, and liver function tests showing elevated levels of alanine aminotransferase (633 U/L) and aspartate aminotransferase (131 U/L). Other lab results include elevated D-dimer levels and lactate dehydrogenase (730 IU/L).

The patient's assessment and plan include:

1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient is stable off of Levophed for over 24 hours. Dobutamine should be decreased to maintain cardiac index (CI) > 2.5, and closely monitor cardiac output and diuresis. Recheck mean arterial pressure (MAP) and CI in one hour, and continue to hold Levophed.

2. Acute on chronic heart failure (CHF): This is related to fluid resuscitation for sepsis. Goal is to maintain a negative fluid balance of 400-500 mL over the next 24 hours. Watch output closely to avoid exacerbating cardiogenic shock, and repeat pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP), mixed venous oxygen saturation (ScvO2), CI, and systemic vascular resistance (SVR) every 8 hours.

3. Atrial fibrillation (A-fib): The patient is not symptomatic, and the heart rate is well-controlled. Started on digoxin yesterday with a loading dose, and will switch to maintenance dose afterward. Consider cardioversion when other issues improve, likely requiring three weeks of therapeutic INR before proceeding. Consider biventricular pacing.

   -Recheck MAP
/CI imn one hour

 Related to fluid resuscitation for sepsis.

   -Watch output closely so as not to exacerbate cardiogenic shock

   - Touch-base w/ EP re: ?Cardioversion when other issues improve. Likely

   P.
   - con
t tele

   -cont nafcillin to complete a 2 week course (day #1=[**2114-4-24**])

 [**1-22**] multifactorial shock, LFT
s trending down; U/S neg

s improving.

   .

 Direct. Source unclear. Alkaline phosphatase not

s KUB

Slowly increasing. [**1-22**] ATN in the setting of shock +/- contrast

   - Back-off on Lasix tomorrow if Cr returns >2.0
   - Cont trend UOP, Cr

 Hct stable; unclear baseline; recent GIB w/ C-scope showing

   -trend Hct daily
   .
   .

 presumed [**1-22**] chronic lumbar back disease, but will

 well-controlled

Summary:
The patient is a 64-year-old male with a medical history of nonischemic dilated cardiomyopathy (ejection fraction 25%), severe aortic stenosis, rheumatic mitral stenosis, diabetes mellitus, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, obstructive sleep apnea, and pulmonary hypertension. The patient was admitted to the hospital with dyspnea on exertion and transferred for further evaluation of aortic stenosis. Upon admission, he developed MSSA bacteremia, septic shock, and cardiogenic shock. 

The patient's current medications include dobutamine at 5 mcg/kg/min, heparin sodium infusion, furosemide (Lasix) at 15 mg/hour, famotidine, and tramadol for pain. The patient has refused the insertion of a nasogastric tube.

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 36.4°C (97.5°F), heart rate of 88 bpm (84-106), blood pressure of 95/51 mmHg (62/34-99/62), respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute (10-20), oxygen saturation of 98% on room air, and atrial fibrillation. The patient's weight is 121.1 kg, and height is 69 inches.

Laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 13.4-14.3 thousand/mm³, hemoglobin of 28-30.

   # Cardiogenic shock: Yesterday we were able to wean the patient
   completely off dobutamine; he maintained MAPs in 70s and his calculated
   CI was 1.9, which is evidence that he is getting over the
   septic/cardiogenic shock. Therefore, from a hemodynamic standpoint
   there is no longer need for his swan-ganz and cordis. However, we will
   keep the swan-ganz and cordis in place at this time for two reasons:
   first, pulmonary will be coming by to evaluate his pulmonary
   hypertension and they may need the swan-ganz catheter to do their NO
   trial; second, the cordis is being currently used for venous access
   because he has very difficult-to-access peripheral veins. Therefore, we
   will need to get a PICC placed before the cordis can be removed.
   - Goal MAPs >65
   - switch lasix gtt to lasix bolus 90mg Q6H, goal neg -1L to -2L x 24
   hrs; be careful not to overdiurese him,
   - maintain Hct>30%
   - PICC line placement
   - Pulmonary consult to evaluate pulmonary hypertension and possible use
   of sildenafil
   .
   # Acute on chronic CHF
 Related to fluid resuscitation for sepsis.
   -Switch to lasix bolus, goal neg 1-2L for 24hours.
   -Watch output closely, ensuring that he is not much more than 2 L
   negative in 24 hours, because getting too much fluid off of him would
   result in decreased preload leading to decreased cardiac output, and
   given his aortic stenosis he might not be able to maintain his MAPs.
   -f/u PM lytes (2pm)
   .
   # A fib: Not symptomatic. Rate well controlled in the 80s on digoxin.
   Will potentially need cardioversion in the future, and it might even
   improve his cardiac output. If we decide to do cardioversion sooner
   than 3 weeks, we may need an echo to check for clot to prevent stroke.
   - con
t tele
   - switch to PO digoxin
   - f/u digoxin level tomorrow in AM
   .
   #  MSSA bacteremia - unclear source; WBC# and fever curve trending
   down, surveillance Cx neg to date.
   -cont nafcillin to complete a 2 week course (day #1=[**2114-4-24**], day
   #14=[**2114-5-8**])
   .
   #Liver failure. The transaminitis from before is now resolving, was
   likely due to shock liver given all findings. However, his INR is still
   high at 2.1, so we will recheck LFTs tomorrow in the morning.
   - recheck LFTs.
   -avoid hepatotoxic medications
   -tylenol 2gm max/24 hrs
   .
   #Hyperbilirubinemia
 Direct. Source unclear. Alkaline phosphatase not
   elevated. RUQ ultrasound on admission without evidence of
   cholecystitis. Could this be [**Doctor Last Name **]
   - Monitor daily
   #Nausea/Vomiting/Conspitation/Diarrhea. The patient is no longer
   experiencing n/v and his constipation is resolved with stopping opioid
   analgesic and starting aggressive bowel regimen. In fact, now he has
   diarrhea. He has a negative c. diff.
   - Decrease bowel regimen to reduce diarrhea.
   - do a rectal to check for impaction
   #AS
 His acute issues have now resolved and he will be a candidate for
   treatment of AS.
   - Valvuloplasty with Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 5279**] on Friday PM. This may help decrease the
   pulmonary hypertension.
   .
   #ARF
 Although his Cr is 1.7, it is stable. Most likely his ARF is
   related not only to lasix, but also due to renal vein congestion
   preventing full and proper blood flow out of the kidney. As his volume
   status improves and he becomes less volume overloaded and as we wean
   the lasix, we can expect to see his Cr trend down.
   - Back-off on Lasix if Cr returns >2.0, otherwise continue lasix now in
   boluses.
   - Cont trend UOP, Cr
   - Urine lytes showed he was pre-renal with FE BUN 28.4 (less than the
   cut off of 30-35).
   .
   #Anemia
 Hct stable; unclear baseline; recent GIB w/ C-scope showing
   colonic AVM that was cauterized
   -trend Hct daily
   .
   #Low back pain
 presumed [**1-22**] chronic lumbar back disease, but will
   monitor for evidence of complication of bacteremia (epidural abscess)
   - On tramadol for this, helping a little bit but not completely.
   - limit tylenol
   - consider imaging of back if pain worsens or neuro status changes
   .
   #Thrombocytopenia. His thrombocytopenia was likely a component of
   shock, liver failure, and bone marrow suppression from his bacteremia.
   It is now resolving and platelets are actually increasing today.
   -trend daily
   .
   #DM
 well-controlled
   -cont basal, SS insulin
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia
   -cont statin
   .

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of nonischemic dilated cardiomyopathy, severe aortic stenosis (AS), rheumatic mitral stenosis (MS), diabetes mellitus (DM), chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), and pulmonary hypertension admitted to the ICU for further evaluation of AS. The patient presented with dobutamine-responsive cardiogenic shock and MSSA bacteremia, septic shock, and cardiogenic shock.

The patient's hemodynamic parameters have improved, and he has been weaned off dobutamine. His mean arterial pressure (MAP) is in the 70s, and his cardiac index (CI) is 1.9, indicating that he is recovering from septic/cardiogenic shock. However, the patient still requires hemodynamic monitoring, and the swan-ganz and cordis catheters will be kept in place for further evaluation and access.

The patient's pulmonary edema has significantly improved, and his bowel function has normalized. He no longer experiences nausea, vomiting, or constipation but now has diarrhea. The patient's atrial fibrillation (A-fib) is well-controlled on digoxin, but he may require cardioversion in the future to potentially improve his cardiac output. The source of MSSA bacteremia is unclear, and the patient will continue receiving nafcillin for a two-week course.

Liver function tests

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 64-year-old male with nonischemic dilated cardiomyopathy, severe aortic stenosis, rheumatic mitral stenosis, diabetes mellitus, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), and pulmonary hypertension. The patient was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for further evaluation of aortic stenosis and is now being treated for MSSA bacteremia, septic shock, and cardiogenic shock.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 36.8°C (98.2°F), heart rate of 75 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 96/60 mmHg to 116/79 mmHg, respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute, oxygen saturation of 98% on room air, and atrial fibrillation as the heart rhythm. The patient's weight is 121.1 kg, and height is 69 inches.

The patient's physical examination reveals a crescendo/decrescendo murmur, normal S1 and S2 heart sounds, crackles at the lower lung fields bilaterally, and trace pitting edema. Laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, hemoglobin, lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), alkaline phosphatase, and bilirubin levels. The patient's platelet count is stable, and he has mild hyperkalemia. Renal function tests indicate acute kidney injury (AKI), possibly due to septic shock and contrast nephropathy.

The patient's current medications include heparin sodium, furosemide (Lasix), famotidine (Pepcid), and nafcillin for MSSA bacteremia. He is also on maintenance doses of digoxin for atrial fibrillation and basal subcutaneous insulin for diabetes mellitus. Other medications include statins for hyperlipidemia and low-sodium diet for nutrition.

The patient's care plan includes weaning off dobutamine, maintaining mean arterial pressures (MAPs) above 65, switching Lasix from a continuous infusion to bolus dosing, ensuring negative fluid balance of 1-2 liters within 24 hours, and monitoring for signs of overdiuresis. A pulmonary consult has been requested to evaluate pulmonary hypertension and potential use of sildenafil. The patient's aortic stenosis requires surgical repair, but he needs to clear the infection before consideration for surgery. A computed tomography (CT) consult has been requested.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's cardiac function may deteriorate, leading to decreased cardiac output and hypotension.
2. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's renal function is already impaired, and further deterioration may occur due to ongoing sepsis, use of nephrotoxic drugs, or inadequate fluid management.
3. Infection: The patient has MSSA bacteremia and may develop further infections, especially if immunosuppressive medications are used.
4. Liver failure: The patient's liver enzymes are elevated, indicating potential liver dysfunction. Continued monitoring and supportive care are necessary.
5. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is stable, but there is a low-intermediate probability of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT). Monitoring platelet counts and considering alternative anticoagulation may be needed.
6. Anemia: The patient has a stable hemoglobin level, but ongoing gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB) and chronic lumbar back disease may contribute to anemia. Close monitoring of hemoglobin levels is recommended.
7. Hyperbilirubinemia: The patient has elevated bilirubin levels, and the source needs to be identified. Monitoring liver function tests and considering additional investigations, such as imaging, may be necessary.
8. Pulmonary complications: The patient's COPD and OSA put him at risk for respiratory complications, such as pneumonia or exacerbations of his pre-existing lung diseases.
9. Contrast-induced nephropathy: The patient received contrast during imaging, which may have contributed to AKI. Further evaluation

   64 M w/ nonischemic dilated cardiomyopathy (EF 25%), severe AS,
   rheumatic MS, DM, COPD, OSA & pulm HTN admitted to OSH with DOE,
   transferred for further evaluation of AS, now with MSSA bacteremia,
   septic shock, and cardiogenic shock.
   .
   # Cardiogenic shock: Yesterday we were able to wean the patient
   completely off dobutamine; he maintained MAPs in 70s and his calculated
   CI was 1.9, which is evidence that he is getting over the
   septic/cardiogenic shock. Therefore, from a hemodynamic standpoint
   there is no longer need for his swan-ganz and cordis. However, we will
   keep the swan-ganz and cordis in place at this time for two reasons:
   first, pulmonary will be coming by to evaluate his pulmonary
   hypertension and they may need the swan-ganz catheter to do their NO
   trial; second, the cordis is being currently used for venous access
   because he has very difficult-to-access peripheral veins. Therefore, we
   will need to get a PICC placed before the cordis can be removed.
   - Goal MAPs >65
   - switch lasix gtt to lasix bolus 90mg Q6H, goal neg -1L to -2L x 24
   hrs; be careful not to overdiurese him,
   - maintain Hct>30%
   - PICC line placement
   - Pulmonary consult to evaluate pulmonary hypertension and possible use
   of sildenafil
   .
   # Acute on chronic CHF
 Related to fluid resuscitation for sepsis.
   -Switch to lasix bolus, goal neg 1-2L for 24hours.
   -Watch output closely, ensuring that he is not much more than 2 L
   negative in 24 hours, because getting too much fluid off of him would
   result in decreased preload leading to decreased cardiac output, and
   given his aortic stenosis he might not be able to maintain his MAPs.
   -f/u PM lytes (2pm)
   .
   # A fib: Not symptomatic. Rate well controlled. On Digoxin now, will
   potentially need cardioversion in the future but right now it
s not the
   priority.
   - con
t tele
   - switch to PO digoxin
   - f/u digoxin level tomorrow in AM
   .

   down, surveillance Cx neg to date.
   -cont nafcillin to complete a 2 week course (day #1=[**2114-4-24**], day
   #14=[**2114-5-8**])
   .
   #Liver failure. The transaminitis from before is now resolving, was
   likely due to shock liver given all findings. However, his INR is still
   high at 2.1,
   -appreciate liver consult
   -trend LFT's
   -avoid hepatotoxic medications
   -tylenol 2gm max/24 hrs
   .
   #Hyperbilirubinemia
 Direct. Source unclear. Alkaline phosphatase not
   elevated. RUQ ultrasound on admission without evidence of
   cholecystitis. Could this be [**Doctor Last Name **]
   - Monitor daily
   #Nausea/Vomiting/Conspitation/Diarrhea. The patient is no longer
   experiencing n/v and his constipation is resolved with stopping opioid
   analgesic and starting aggressive bowel regimen. In fact, now he has
   diarrhea. He has a negative c. diff.
   - Decrease bowel regimen to reduce diarrhea.
   - do a rectal to check for impaction
   #Thrombocytopenia
 Platelets stable. Likely a component of shock,
   liver failure; low-intermediate prob for HIT; no evidence DIC by labs.
   Likely [**1-22**] sepsis; now resolving.
   -trend daily
   -appreciate heme/onc recs
   .
   #AS - [**Location (un) **] 0.8 cm2 in cath lab; surgical repair candidate given symptoms
   of CHF however will need to clear infection prior to consideration for
   surgery, sustain pressures off pressors.
   -appreciate CT [**Doctor First Name **] consult
   - Note possible valvuloplasty in next 72 hours (once Dobutamine is
   off).
   .
   #ARF
Slowly increasing. [**1-22**] ATN in the setting of shock +/- contrast
   nephropathy , now Lasix drip. Baseline = 1.2 = 2.
   - Back-off on Lasix tomorrow if Cr returns >2.0
   - Cont trend UOP, Cr
   - F/u urine lytes to ensure pre-renal
   .
   #Anemia
 Hct stable; unclear baseline; recent GIB w/ C-scope showing
   colonic AVM that was cauterized
   -trend Hct daily
   .
   .
   #Low back pain
 presumed [**1-22**] chronic lumbar back disease, but will
   monitor for evidence of complication of bacteremia (epidural abscess)
   -low dose narcotics prn
   -limit tylenol
   -consider imaging of back if pain worsens or neuro status changes
   .
   #DM
 well-controlled
   -cont basal, SS insulin
   .

   -cont statin
   .

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 64-year-old male with a medical history of nonischemic dilated cardiomyopathy, severe aortic stenosis, rheumatic mitral stenosis, diabetes mellitus, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, obstructive sleep apnea, and pulmonary hypertension. The patient was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for further evaluation of aortic stenosis and is currently being treated for MSSA bacteremia, septic shock, and cardiogenic shock.

The patient has shown improvement in hemodynamics, as he was able to wean off dobutamine and maintain mean arterial pressures (MAPs) in the 70s and a calculated cardiac index (CI) of 1.9, indicating better cardiac output. However, the patient still requires close monitoring and management of various medical complications.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Cardiogenic Shock: Although the patient has shown improvement, there is still a need for close monitoring of hemodynamic parameters, and the patient may require continued support with medications like digoxin and careful fluid management.

2. Acute on Chronic Heart Failure: The patient has a history of chronic heart failure, and recent fluid resuscitation for sepsis has resulted in acute exacerbation. It is important to balance fluid administration to prevent both under-resuscitation and over-resuscitation, which could lead to decreased preload and cardiac output.

   # A fib: Not symptomatic. Rate well controlled in the 80s on digoxin.
   Will potentially need cardioversion in the future, and it might even
   improve his cardiac output. If we decide to do cardioversion sooner
   than 3 weeks, we may need an echo to check for clot to prevent stroke.
   - con
t tele
   - switch to PO digoxin
   - f/u digoxin level tomorrow in AM
   .
   #  MSSA bacteremia - unclear source; WBC# and fever curve trending
   down, surveillance Cx neg to date.
   -cont nafcillin to complete a 2 week course (day #1=[**2114-4-24**], day
   #14=[**2114-5-8**])
   .
   #Liver failure. The transaminitis from before is now resolving, was
   likely due to shock liver given all findings. However, his INR is still
   high at 2.1, so we will recheck LFTs tomorrow in the morning.
   - recheck LFTs.
   -avoid hepatotoxic medications
   -tylenol 2gm max/24 hrs
   .
   #Hyperbilirubinemia
 Direct. Source unclear. Alkaline phosphatase not
   elevated. RUQ ultrasound on admission without evidence of
   cholecystitis. Could this be [**Doctor Last Name **]
   - Monitor daily
   #Nausea/Vomiting/Conspitation/Diarrhea. The patient is no longer
   experiencing n/v and his constipation is resolved with stopping opioid
   analgesic and starting aggressive bowel regimen. In fact, now he has
   diarrhea. He has a negative c. diff.
   - Decrease bowel regimen to reduce diarrhea.
   - do a rectal to check for impaction
   #AS
 His acute issues have now resolved and he will be a candidate for
   treatment of AS.
   - Valvuloplasty with Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 5279**] on Friday PM. This may help decrease the
   pulmonary hypertension.
   .
   #ARF
 Although his Cr is 1.7, it is stable. Most likely his ARF is
   related not only to lasix, but also due to renal vein congestion
   preventing full and proper blood flow out of the kidney. As his volume
   status improves and he becomes less volume overloaded and as we wean
   the lasix, we can expect to see his Cr trend down.
   - Back-off on Lasix if Cr returns >2.0, otherwise continue lasix now in
   boluses.
   - Cont trend UOP, Cr
   - Urine lytes showed he was pre-renal with FE BUN 28.4 (less than the
   cut off of 30-35).
   .
   #Anemia
 Hct stable; unclear baseline; recent GIB w/ C-scope showing
   colonic AVM that was cauterized
   -trend Hct daily
   .
   #Low back pain
 presumed [**1-22**] chronic lumbar back disease, but will
   monitor for evidence of complication of bacteremia (epidural abscess)
   - On tramadol for this, helping a little bit but not completely.
   - limit tylenol
   - consider imaging of back if pain worsens or neuro status changes
   .
   #Thrombocytopenia. His thrombocytopenia was likely a component of
   shock, liver failure, and bone marrow suppression from his bacteremia.
   It is now resolving and platelets are actually increasing today.
   -trend daily
   .
   #DM
 well-controlled
   -cont basal, SS insulin
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia
   -cont statin
   .

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of nonischemic dilated cardiomyopathy, severe aortic stenosis (AS), rheumatic mitral stenosis (MS), diabetes mellitus (DM), chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), and pulmonary hypertension. He was admitted with dyspnea on exertion and evaluated for severe AS. He now presents with MSSA bacteremia, septic shock, and cardiogenic shock.

Medical Complications:

1. Cardiogenic Shock: The patient had cardiogenic shock, but he is improving as evidenced by being able to wean off dobutamine and maintaining mean arterial pressures (MAPs) in the 70s and a calculated cardiac index (CI) of 1.9.

2. Acute on Chronic Congestive Heart Failure (CHF): The patient has acute exacerbation of chronic CHF related to fluid resuscitation for sepsis. The goal is to achieve negative fluid balance of 1-2 liters in 24 hours without overdiuresis.

3. Atrial Fibrillation (AF): The patient has AF with a well-controlled heart rate in the 80s on digoxin. There is a potential need for cardioversion in the future, which may improve cardiac output. An echocardiogram will be necessary to check for clot before cardioversion to prevent stroke.

4

Summary:
The patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of nonischemic dilated cardiomyopathy, severe aortic stenosis (AS), rheumatic mitral valve disease (MS), diabetes mellitus (DM), chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), and pulmonary hypertension admitted to the ICU for further evaluation of AS. He presented with dyspnea on exertion (DOE) and was transferred from another hospital due to MSSA bacteremia and cardiogenic shock.

The patient has shown improvement over the past 24 hours, with successful weaning off dobutamine and maintaining mean arterial pressures (MAPs) in the 70s and a calculated cardiac index (CI) of 1.9. This suggests that he is recovering from septic and cardiogenic shock. However, the patient still requires hemodynamic monitoring with a pulmonary artery catheter (swan-ganz) and cordis for venous access due to difficult-to-access peripheral veins. A PICC line placement is planned.

The patient's current medical issues include acute on chronic congestive heart failure (CHF) related to fluid resuscitation for sepsis, atrial fibrillation (AF) well-controlled with digoxin, MSSA bacteremia treated with nafcillin, liver failure multifactorial in origin, hyperbilirubinemia with unclear source, nausea possibly due to medication side effects or ileus, thromb

   64 M w/ nonischemic dilated cardiomyopathy (EF 25%), severe AS,
   rheumatic MS, DM, COPD, OSA & pulm HTN admitted to OSH with DOE,
   transferred for further evaluation of AS, now with MSSA bacteremia,
   septic shock, and cardiogenic shock.
   .
   # Cardiogenic shock: Yesterday we were able to wean the patient
   completely off dobutamine; he maintained MAPs in 70s and his calculated
   CI was 1.9, which is evidence that he is getting over the
   septic/cardiogenic shock. Therefore, from a hemodynamic standpoint
   there is no longer need for his swan-ganz and cordis. However, we will
   keep the swan-ganz and cordis in place at this time for two reasons:
   first, pulmonary will be coming by to evaluate his pulmonary
   hypertension and they may need the swan-ganz catheter to do their NO
   trial; second, the cordis is being currently used for venous access
   because he has very difficult-to-access peripheral veins. Therefore, we
   will need to get a PICC placed before the cordis can be removed.
   - Goal MAPs >65
   - switch lasix gtt to lasix bolus 90mg Q6H, goal neg -1L to -2L x 24
   hrs; be careful not to overdiurese him,
   - maintain Hct>30%
   - PICC line placement
   - Pulmonary consult to evaluate pulmonary hypertension and possible use
   of sildenafil
   .
   # Acute on chronic CHF
 Related to fluid resuscitation for sepsis.
   -Switch to lasix bolus, goal neg 1-2L for 24hours.
   -Watch output closely, ensuring that he is not much more than 2 L
   negative in 24 hours, because getting too much fluid off of him would
   result in decreased preload leading to decreased cardiac output, and
   given his aortic stenosis he might not be able to maintain his MAPs.
   -f/u PM lytes (2pm)
   .
   # A fib: Not symptomatic. Rate well controlled in the 80s on digoxin.
   Will potentially need cardioversion in the future, and it might even
   improve his cardiac output. If we decide to do cardioversion sooner
   than 3 weeks, we may need an echo to check for clot to prevent stroke.
   - con
t tele
   - switch to PO digoxin
   - f/u digoxin level tomorrow in AM
   .
   #  MSSA bacteremia - unclear source; WBC# and fever curve trending
   down, surveillance Cx neg to date.
   -cont nafcillin to complete a 2 week course (day #1=[**2114-4-24**], day
   #14=[**2114-5-8**])
   .
   #Liver failure. The transaminitis from before is now resolving, was
   likely due to shock liver given all findings. However, his INR is still
   high at 2.1, so we will recheck LFTs tomorrow in the morning.
   - recheck LFTs.
   -avoid hepatotoxic medications
   -tylenol 2gm max/24 hrs
   .
   #Hyperbilirubinemia
 Direct. Source unclear. Alkaline phosphatase not
   elevated. RUQ ultrasound on admission without evidence of
   cholecystitis. Could this be [**Doctor Last Name **]
   - Monitor daily
   #Nausea/Vomiting/Conspitation/Diarrhea. The patient is no longer
   experiencing n/v and his constipation is resolved with stopping opioid
   analgesic and starting aggressive bowel regimen. In fact, now he has
   diarrhea. He has a negative c. diff.
   - Decrease bowel regimen to reduce diarrhea.
   - do a rectal to check for impaction
   #AS
 His acute issues have now resolved and he will be a candidate for
   treatment of AS.
   - Valvuloplasty with Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 5279**] on Friday PM. This may help decrease the
   pulmonary hypertension.
   .
   #ARF
 Although his Cr is 1.7, it is stable. Most likely his ARF is
   related not only to lasix, but also due to renal vein congestion
   preventing full and proper blood flow out of the kidney. As his volume
   status improves and he becomes less volume overloaded and as we wean
   the lasix, we can expect to see his Cr trend down.
   - Back-off on Lasix if Cr returns >2.0, otherwise continue lasix now in
   boluses.
   - Cont trend UOP, Cr
   - Urine lytes showed he was pre-renal with FE BUN 28.4 (less than the
   cut off of 30-35).
   .
   #Anemia
 Hct stable; unclear baseline; recent GIB w/ C-scope showing
   colonic AVM that was cauterized
   -trend Hct daily
   .
   #Low back pain
 presumed [**1-22**] chronic lumbar back disease, but will
   monitor for evidence of complication of bacteremia (epidural abscess)
   - On tramadol for this, helping a little bit but not completely.
   - limit tylenol
   - consider imaging of back if pain worsens or neuro status changes
   .
   #Thrombocytopenia. His thrombocytopenia was likely a component of
   shock, liver failure, and bone marrow suppression from his bacteremia.
   It is now resolving and platelets are actually increasing today.
   -trend daily
   .
   #DM
 well-controlled
   -cont basal, SS insulin
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia
   -cont statin
   .
